member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Sqrt(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex)
member.summary: Calculate the square root of a BigComplex number. The second root can be found by the conjugate of the result. You can use this method to get the square root of a negative value (including a BigDecimal value). e.g. BigComplex z = BigComplex.Sqrt(-5);
member.returns: The positive square root as a BigComplex number.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks: Ignoring style parameter for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks:
Supported formats: 1. Ordinary real number (integer or floating point), e.g. 12345, 123.45, 123.45e67 etc. The 'e' for exponent can be lower or upper-case, as with normal floating point syntax. 2. Format used by System.Complex.ToString(), with angle brackets and a semicolon. Square brackets, curly braces, parentheses, or no brackets at all are also supported. 3. Standard notation used in maths is supported (e.g. a + bi), with either i or j. The i or j can come before or after the imaginary number, and it can be lower or upper-case.
Also note: - Leading, trailing, or any other whitespace is ignored. - Digit grouping characters (e.g. thousands separators) are allowed, including commas or periods (culture-specific), underscores, and thin spaces. - The real part must come before the imaginary part. In the math notation, either the real or imaginary part can be omitted. - The format (x, y) is NOT supported, because we need to allow the commas as a decimal points (and they could also appear as digit grouping characters). - A null or empty string is taken to be 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String)
member.returns: The BigComplex value represented by the string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.TryParse(System.String,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex@)
member.param: The BigComplex value represented by the string.
member.returns: If the attempt to parse the value succeeded.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks:
I've added support for an alternate format to the one used by Complex.ToString(), namely the conventional "a + bi" notation (and it's variations). Both 'i' and 'j' are supported for the imaginary unit, hopefully to keep both mathematicians and engineers happy. Upper-case 'I' means the 'i' is placed after the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + 34i Lower-case 'i' means the 'i' is placed before the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + i34 Upper-case 'J' means the 'j' is placed after the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + 34j Lower-case 'j' means the 'j' is placed before the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + j34 If there's no imaginary part, the real part will be formatted like a normal real value. If there's no real part, the imaginary part will be formatted like a normal real value with the i or j placed as a prefix or suffix according to the format specifier. If the value is negative, the sign will come before the number with i or j. e.g. -1.23i, -i1.23, -1.23j, -j1.23
As for the default format mimicking the format used by Complex.ToString(), I have seen this as (x, y) as well as <x; y> (i.e. angle brackets and semicolon instead of parentheses and comma). I've used the latter option here, which matches the source code.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Format the BigComplex as a string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString
member.summary: Express the complex number as a string in the usual algebraic format. This differs from Complex.ToString(), which outputs strings like (x, y).
member.returns: The complex number as a string.

member.name: T:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary: Operators and methods for comparing BigDecimal.
Power, root, exponential, and logarithm methods for BigDecimal.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.CompareTo(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: Although the specification says any negative value indicates the "this" operand comes before the "other" operand (similar for positive values), in this method the result is constrained to only 3 possible values: -1 means "this" comes before (and is less than) "other" 0 means they are equal 1 means "this" comes after (and is greater than) "other"

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComputePi
member.remarks: The Chudnovsky algorithm used here was the one used to generate Ï€ to 6.2 trillion decimal places, the current world record.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComputeTau
member.summary: Compute the value of tau (Ï„), equal to 2 * pi (2Ï€).
member.returns: The value of Ï„ to the current number of significant figures.

member.name: F:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._phi
member.summary: Cached value for Ï†, the golden ratio.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ComputePhi
member.summary: Compute the value of phi (Ï†), the golden ratio.
member.returns: The value of Ï† to the current number of significant figures.

member.name: F:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._ln10
member.summary: Cached value for Log(10), the natural logarithm of 10.
member.remarks: This value is cached because of it's use in the Log() method. We don't want to have to recompute Log(10) every time we call Log().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Half)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the Half, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the Half, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Single)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the float, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the float, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Double)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the double, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the double, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ConvertFromFloatingPoint``1(``0)
member.summary: Helper method to convert a standard binary floating point type (Half, float, or double) to a BigDecimal.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ConvertToFloatingPoint``1(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Helper method to convert a BigDecimal to a standard binary floating point type (Half, float, or double).
member.remarks: If the BigDecimal is outside the range for this type, this method will return negative or positive infinity as needed, without throwing an exception.
member.typeparam: The standard binary floating point type.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Significand
member.summary: The part of a number in scientific notation or in floating-point representation consisting of its significant digits. Also known as the mantissa.
member.remarks: In BigDecimal values, no trailing zeros are retained in the significand; rather, the exponent is adjusted instead. This minimised the size of the BigInteger being used to store the value. This varies from the scientific meaning of significant digits, which can include significant trailing zeros, but it seems like the right design choice here.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Sign
member.remarks: The same convention is used as for BigInteger: -1 means negative 0 means zero 1 means positive

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.NumSigFigs
member.summary: Get the number of significant figures.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.MaxSigFigs
member.summary: This property determines the maximum number of significant figures to keep in a BigDecimal value. After any calculation, the result will be rounded to this many significant figures. This not only helps control memory usage by controlling the size of the significand, but also determines when to halt numerical methods, e.g. for calculating a square root or logarithm. If this property is modified, only new objects and calculations are affected by it. If you want to reduce the number of significant figures in an existing value, use RoundSigFigs().

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.IsCanonical(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Checks if the value is in its canonical state, which for BigDecimal means the value should be zero or the significand should be a number not divisible by 10 (i.e. represented by the smallest possible BigInteger). If the significand is 0, then the exponent should also be 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Round(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Int32,System.MidpointRounding)
member.remarks: The default rounding mode of MidpointRounding.ToEven is the same as used by similar methods in .NET Core.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSigFigs(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Nullable{System.Numerics.BigInteger},System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Round off a value to a certain number of significant figures.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Truncate(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Frac(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Return the fractional part of the value.
member.remarks: There are multiple ways to define the frac() function for negative numbers. (Refer to the Wikipedia link below.) The definition used in this implementation simply takes the digits to the right of the decimal point, with the sign matching the argument. e.g. Frac(12.345) => 0.345 Frac(-12.345) => -0.345 The following expression will be true for both positive and negative numbers: x == Truncate(x) + Frac(x)

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Floor(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Ceiling(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSignificand(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Divide by a power of 10 and round off to the nearest integer.
member.remarks: The default rounding mode of MidpointRounding.ToEven is the same as used by similar methods in .NET Core.
member.param: The BigInteger value to round off.
The power of 10 (number of digits to cut).
member.returns: The rounded off result of the division.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSigFigs(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Given a significand and exponent, and a maximum number of significant figures, determine the new significand and exponent.
member.remarks: The default rounding mode of MidpointRounding.ToEven is the same as used by similar methods in .NET Core.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftBy(System.Numerics.BigInteger)
member.summary: Move the decimal point to the right by the specified number of places. This will effectively multiply the significand by 10 and decrement the exponent to maintain the same value, the specified number of times. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftToSigFigs(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Shift such that the significand has a certain number of significant digits. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ShiftToExp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Shift such that the exponent has a certain value. NB: The value will probably not be canonical after calling this method, so it should only be used on temporary variables.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Align(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Adjust the parts of one of the values so both have the same exponent. Two new objects will be returned.

member.summary: Modify the provided significand and exponent as needed to find the canonical form. Static form of the method, for use in the constructor.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary:
Format the BigDecimal as a string. Supported formats are the usual: D, E, F, G, N, P, and R.
Although "D" is normally only used by integral types, in this case both the significand and exponent will be formatted as integers. An secondary code "U" is provided, which follows the precision (if given). - If omitted, the exponent (if present) will be formatted with the usual E[-+]999 format. - If present, the exponent is formatted with "Ã—10" instead of "E" and the exponent digits will be rendered as superscript. Also, a "+" sign is not used for positive exponents, and the exponent digits are not zero-padded. Example: "E7U" will format as per usual (E with 7 decimal digits), except using Unicode characters for the exponent part. Codes "R" and "D" will produce the same output. However, the Unicode flag is undefined with "R", because Parse() doesn't support superscript exponents.
member.exception: If the format specifier is invalid.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Format the BigDecimal as a string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.PreformatFixed
member.summary: From a BigDecimal, extract two strings of digits that would appear if the number was written in fixed-point format (i.e. without an exponent). Sign is ignored.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatFixed(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the BigDecimal as a fixed-point number with a given precision.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatFixedSigFigs(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format as fixed point, except in this case the precision is the number of significant figures, not the number of decimal places. Note, this is not technically formatting as significant figures, since trailing 0s following the decimal point are not retained, as per the usual format for "G".

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatScientific(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the value using scientific notation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatExponent(System.String,System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the exponent part of scientific notation.
member.param: The original format code (e.g. E, e, G, or g). We need to know this to determine whether to use an upper- or lower-case 'E'.
Whether to use Unicode or standard format.
The minimum number of digits in the exponent (typically 3 for E and 2 for G). Relevant for standard (non-Unicode) format only.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
â—‹ Match if at the beginning of the string.
â—‹ "format" capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [D-GNPRd-gnpr].
â—‹ "precision" capture group.
â—‹ Match a Unicode digit atomically any number of times.
â—‹ "unicode" capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Uu] atomically, optionally.
â—‹ Match if at the end of the string or if before an ending newline.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.GetDigitGroupingCharacterSet(System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo)
member.summary: Get a regular expression character set containing the thousands separators. This includes: - the usual comma or period (depending on the culture specified by the NumberFormatInfo) - underscores - thin spaces

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: This two-argument variation of the Atan() method comes originally from FORTRAN. If x is non-negative, it will find the same result as Atan(y / x). If x is negative, the result will be offset by Ï€. The purpose of the method is to produce a correct value for the polar angle when converting from cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates. It also avoids division by 0 exceptions.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2Pi(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Computes the arc-tangent for the quotient of two values and divides the result by pi.
member.exception: If x and y both equal 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.CartesianToPolar(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Convert cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates.
member.returns: A tuple containing the radius (r) and phase angle (theta).

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.PolarToCartesian(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Convert polar coordinates to cartesian coordinates.
member.returns: A tuple containing the x and y coordinates.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.NormalizeAngle(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal@)
member.summary: Shift given angle to the equivalent angle in the interval [-Ï€, Ï€).

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.CompareTo(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational)
member.remarks: Although the specification says any negative value indicates the "this" operand comes before the "br" operand (similar for positive values), in this method the result is constrained to only 3 possible values: -1 means "this" comes before (and is less than) "br" 0 means they are equal 1 means "this" comes after (and is greater than) "br"

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.Numerator
member.summary: The numerator of the rational number.
member.remarks: This can be any integer.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.Denominator
member.summary: The denominator of the rational number.
member.remarks: This value should always be positive. It should never 0 because this would not be a rational number. It should also never be negative. The sign of the rational is determined by the numerator.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.Sign
member.remarks: The same convention is used as for BigInteger: -1 means negative 0 means zero 1 means positive

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.#ctor(System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Numerics.BigInteger)
member.summary: Construct a BigRational from two integers, the numerator and denominator. The fraction is automatically reduced to its simplest form.
member.exception: If the denominator is 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.IsCanonical(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational)
member.remarks: A BigRational value should always be kept in canonical form, which means: - reduced to the simplest possible ratio of integers - the denominator should be positive
